I agree that this was the original intent, but the fact of the matter is th=
at the "extension use case" has escaped into the wild.

RFC3864 exists for =
a reason.  It talks about experimental headers, but it also talks about a p=
rovisional repository containing headers that have been "adopted ad-hoc to =
address a locally occurring requirement; some of these have found widesprea=
d use"

Realizing that we are all treading water until HTTPbis is finished,=

I'm looking for comments from people who felt the need to use headers in t=
his way.

> > no longer use the "X-" prefix, very litt=

> 'Extended' headers, as you put it, aren't actually=
 what you think. The 'X-'
> prefix is meant for experimental headers, and t=
hus are only meant to be used in
> private experiments. They're not somethi=
ng that's meant to be seen in the wild,
> but this convention unfortunately=
 gets abused a lot.
> 
> In fact, there's even an I-D to deprecate the futu=
re use of 'X-':
> http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-appsawg-xdash-03
> =

> > Clearly, one could get carried with Extended Headers, however they do =
have
> > their uses.  I'm curious to hear people's opinions and guidelines =
on how,
> > where, and under what situations to use Extended Headers within=
 REST.
> 
> You shouldn't be using 'X-' headers in HTTP except for your own=
 personal
> experiments.
